to himself, too." Reba smiled at Grampa brilliantly. "No, I guess you don't."         *       *       *       *       *  He cleared his throat professorially. "Well, now, in ordinary light the vibrations are perpendicular to the ray in all directions. "That's just nonsense! You all know it. Grampa's no genius. He's just a tinkerer. One day he happened to tinker out the polarizer. He doesn't know how it works any more than I do." "And then you spent everything you got from it on those fool perpetual-motion machines and those crazy longevity schemes when any moron would know they were impossible." "Well, now," Grampa said in bafflement, "it rightly should, you know."         *       *       *       *       *  "We're stuck," Reba said softly. "We might as well admit it. of gravity."  "Well?" Fred prompted.  "It shifts."  "That's impossible," said Junior.  "Not for Fweep," Four replied.  "What do you mean by that?" Joyce suspiciously asked.
